awd_titl_txt: Testing a Goal-Commitment Model of Compassion
awd_abstract_narration:
People are often exposed to the unfair suffering of others.  Learning of starving children, encountering victims of natural disasters, or knowing of others' economic hardships brings out in people a strong emotional reaction most commonly described as compassion.  The experience of compassion typically leads to a desire to help.  Yet, people do not always act on those desires.  Instead, the experience of compassion sometimes causes anxiety and motivates people to protect their own interests and to avoid being helpful to others.  This project considers some fundamental properties of social cognition that may help to account for these divergent responses to compassion -- to help or not to help.  The main focus is on the concept of goal commitment.  The desire to help may not translate into actual helping unless one decides on a way to put that goal into action.  This project aims to identify simple but effective approaches to assist people in acting on their desire to help suffering others.  A series of experiments test whether thinking about helping goals as commitments rather than mere desires will lower the barriers to helping.  Close relationships, families, groups, and entire societies depend upon people's willingness to make sacrifices on behalf of others. By shedding light on the mechanisms for such behavior and the conditions under which it is likely to occur, this project may open up new possibilities for research and interventions that promote helping behavior in a variety of settings.


Witnessing the undeserved suffering of others frequently elicits multiple conflicting goals. One such goal is the desire to help suffering others.  A competing goal is the desire to protect one's self and one's resources of time, money, or effort.  Based on theoretical models of goal pursuit, this project focuses on the role of goal commitment in resolving such multiple conflicting goals.  Five studies test the prediction that committing to a helping goal will lead people to reduce their concerns with self-protection goals, thereby reducing self-focused anxiety and increasing helping behavior in the form of charitable donations.  The studies examine the effects of exposure to suffering, goal commitment, and the cost of helping on charitable giving. The studies also feature assessments of physiological threat as a supplement to self-report measures of distress and anxiety.  In the absence of goal commitment, it is expected that exposure to suffering will increase anxiety and fail to elicit donations.  In the presence of goal commitment, it is expected that exposure to suffering will not increase anxiety and will promote donations. By examining the connections between compassion and anxiety reduction, the research could inform interventions that increase the health benefits of social engagement.

por.por_cntn:
When people see others suffer without deserving it, they typically experience strong emotional reactions called "compassion." These feelings often make people feel conflicted about how to respond, because people often feel a desire to help the person(s) in need but are also aware of the need to protect their own resources of time and money. In this research, we predicted that when people were given instructions to act on their compassionate feelings they would have fewer feelings and cardiovascular symptoms of anxiety.

We conducted six studies to test these predictions, some with college students and some with adults we contacted online. The first two studies from this project showed that encouraging people to act on their compassionate feelings for disaster victims led to increased likelihood of donating to a charity, and this was especially effective when people were feeling unnecessarily financially insecure.

The next two studies were somewhat similar but included an examination of changes in blood flow that are associated with anxiety. When people are anxious, their blood vessels tend to constrict in ways that raise blood pressure and make it harder for the heart to move blood through the body. We wanted to see if encouraging people to act on their compassionate feelings would reduce these cardiovascular effects of anxiety. What we found was that when people were especially unsure about acting on their compassionate feelings, they did show anxiety-related limitations in their blood flow. We also found that when people had better blood flow (i.e., fewer cardiovascular anxiety symptoms) they were more likely to give to charity.

We have conducted two additional studies that also look at anxiety-related blood flow, but we do not yet have results from these studies because it takes a long time to analyze the complex cardiovascular data for each person in the study. We expect to have more information to report from this research later in Fall 2023.

Conducting this research gave us the opportunity to train a diverse group of 10 graduate students and 32 undergraduate students. It also may have some real-world implications, especially for people trying to raise money on behalf of charities or disaster victims. Many such organizations show people images or stories that are intended to have an emotional impact, and specifically to increase people's feelings of compassion. Our research suggests that doing this may only be effective if the person watching is in the right mindset. For someone who's feeling unsure about the value of helping others, a charity's appeal to their emotions may lead to anxiety and a desire to avoid the topic. By contrast, for someone who's feeling clearer about the value or importance of taking action, similar emotional appeals may make them even more willing to invest money or other resources in the charity. It may be important for charities to keep these issues in mind and think about how they can shape or build on people's thoughts about helping behavior. For example, pairing emotional appeals with highly concrete steps towards action could be an effective strategy.
